data.text: Contents
Introduction
It is important that the Trusts maintain clear access routes for all emergency
vehicles, minimise congestion on all sites, and maintain parking areas for staff and visitors.
As a caring and responsible organisation, the Trusts are fully committed to

reducing their carbon footprint and are working in close partnership with local authorities, transport companies, peer groups, etc. to ensure wide variety of transport options are available to staff, patients and visitors are available. As such this policy is developed in accordance with HTM 07-03 “NHS car-parking management, environment and sustainability”.
The Trusts are committed to providing patient and visitor parking in the most
convenient areas of the hospital sites to ensure the easiest access to buildings and departments where appropriate.
This policy covers all staff, patients, visitors, contractors and all other vehicles
using, or intending to use, the parking facilities provided by the Trusts at all locations where the Trusts operate.
At time of print, parking charges applied across site are not yet aligned – this
document will be updated when implementation plan to align is completed. Differences across sites can be seen in Appendix
Scope
This policy applies to all staff, visitors and patients using car parking facilities on

Trust premises. It also applies to those who work at the hospitals but are not employed by the Trusts. This includes agency or temporary workers, volunteers and employees of retail organisations based at the hospital sites.
This policy applies to contractors who must follow the guidelines within the
Trusts' Control of Contractors Policy.
This policy applies to all delivery vehicles, taxis, emergency vehicles, non-
emergency vehicles and public transport providers.
Definitions

table_items.text: An online database provided by 3rd party enforcement for managing concessions and exemptions from parking payments

data.text: Role & responsibilities within the Trust
The Chief executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility on behalf of the Trusts to ensure adequate car parking facilities and sustainable travel options are in place.
Director of operations (estates and facilities)
The Director of Operations (Estates and Facilities) has responsibility for ensuring car parking services are safe, maintained and managed effectively and efficiently.
Head of sustainability
The Head of Sustainability has responsibility for strategic travel planning. Head of security/LSMS
The Head of Security/LSMS is responsible for the day to day management of car parking, providing a car park service and for managing the car parking and travel team.
Car parking officers
Car Parking Officers are responsible for:
Assisting staff, visitors and patients to park safely.
Enforcing the car parking policy by monitoring parking
Assisting and directing visitors to wards and departments.
Managing car parking facilities as required in busy periods and emergency incidents.
Assisting with gritting during extreme weather periods.
Monitoring and reporting any maintenance issues within car parking facilities.
Generally provide assistance to staff and visitors parking such as providing
wheelchairs if required.
Responsible for escorting staff and visitors to car parks when it is dark should they feel vulnerable.
Managers and supervisors
All Managers and Supervisors are responsible for ensuring their staff are made aware of car parking procedures, as well as other travel options and available incentive schemes.
All staff

All Staff are responsible for ensuring that they consider all alternative means of transport to the hospital sites and should they choose to drive to have a valid parking permit, the permit is kept up to date with the correct details at all times; must be displayed appropriately at all times; are paying the correct parking fees; park safely and do not cause obstruction; park within a marked bay within staff car parks only.
All patients and visitors
All Patients and Visitors are responsible for ensuring that they have paid the correct fare, are parked within specified car park locations at all times and follow the car park regulations.
Car park management
Car parking permit fees contributes towards operational costs involved with the
provision of car parking services, subsidising alternative travel options and funds any planned improvements to the car parks.
Responsibility and Liability: The Trust endeavours to provide security measures

on site, including in the car parking areas, however, the Trust or its employees will not be held liable for any loss, damage or theft to vehicles or contents however caused whilst vehicles, including motorcycles and bicycles are on the Trust property. The Trust advise all owners to ensure that all possible security measures are taken, including immobilising all vehicles, removing all valuables and ensuring all vehicles are locked before leaving them.
To help maintain safe Trust sites, all visitors to the site should immediately
report any suspicious persons or incidents to the car park officers either in person or via switchboard for the attention of security.
Malicious Damage: Any proven instances of malicious damage, the Trust
reserve the right to seek recompense to restore the damaged property or equipment.
Zero Tolerance Policy: Car Parking staff are available on site to provide

assistance with parking. The Trust does not tolerate verbal or physical abuse, or the use of inappropriate language or behaviour towards any member of our staff. Any such incident involving staff or a member of the public will be reported and fully investigated.
Extreme Weather: During icy conditions, every effort is made to ensure grounds
are gritted to provide a safe environment. However, it may be necessary to close part of the car park(s) during this time if any unsafe areas remain.
Staff parking
As car parking spaces are limited, staff should consider all alternative means of
travel first (including using the bus, cycling, walking or sharing their journey to work with another member of staff) before they apply for a parking permit.
Parking Permits: All staff wishing to park within the designated hospital grounds
must at all times hold/display a valid parking permit which is issued by the Trusts.
Stopping car park payments: Car park payments can be temporarily suspended
at times when an employee will not using the car parking facilities. This will only apply to members of staff on maternity leave or long term sick leave.
Car parking charges will be reviewed on a bi-annual basis in partnership with
Staff Side and 3 months' notice will be provided should any fees be increased. See Appendix 1 for detail for each side.
Parking on site: As with any car park, parking spaces may not always be

available. Your parking permit only gives staff permission to park; it does not guarantee that a space will be available. This approach ensures that car parking is available on a first come, first served basis.
Staff are only allowed to park within allocated staff car parking areas. Staff are

not allowed at any times to park in either a patient or visitor bay, a bay for emergency vehicles or a disabled bay (unless they display either a permanent or temporary disabled badge) or any other specifically designated bays. Should a staff member be parked within a patient area, they will be liable to either the full patient tariff or enforcement notices.
At all times staff should adhere to the road safety signage and should ensure
that they drive and park in a safe manner as not to endanger pedestrians or other road users.
Disabled parking for staff: Staff members who have been issued with a valid
blue disabled badge must have a staff parking permit in order to park in any designated disabled bays in staff car parks.
Requests for all temporary disabled badges must be processed through the

Occupational Health department. The relevant site Car Parking department must then be contacted to arrange suitable parking arrangements for the agreed interim period. Staff permit charges will apply.
Parking for volunteers
Volunteers can park free of charge on the days that they carry out voluntary
service at the Trust, but must at all times display a valid car parking permit and be parked in the correct designated areas.
Volunteers are allowed to park in staff parking areas and must display a valid
volunteers parking permit.
Training requirements
All Car Parking Officers and management shall be appropriately trained to
appropriate industry standards.
All Car Parking Officers shall be appropriately trained in conflict resolution.
Staff will be fully briefed and trained in respect of all functions, both operational
and administrative relating to car parking control operations.
Students and agency workers
Students completing placements at the Trust and all agency workers that
undertake placements must pay for parking, in line with the rates set out for Trust staff.
Students and agency workers will need to display a valid permit (see section

8.3) and should only park in staff car parking areas. Southend do not currently offer full-time parking permits to students or agency workers - they can apply for an evening and weekend permit but are not eligible to a full-time permit.
Employees of organisations based on Trust premises
Individuals employed by organisations that operate on Trusts premises will be
eligible to park in staff car parking areas, in line with the rates set out for Trust staff.
Contractors parking
Contractors should at all times adhere to site regulations to ensure site safety
and should not cause an obstruction in area.
Contractors should only park in designated areas and at all times adhere to the
regulations as set out in the Trust's Control of Contractors Policy.
Vehicles parked with “an unofficial note/letter” displayed in the window will not
be exempt from formal car parking control measures.
Patient and Visitors parking
Site Information: Site maps, directional signage and notice boards are
available to assist patients and visitors with parking and wayfinding on site.
Visitors are not permitted to park in staff parking areas.
Pay and Display: A Pay and Display System is currently in operation. It

requires patients and visitors to pay for parking and display a ticket on the inside of the vehicle, ensuring it is clearly visible to the Car Parking officers. Pay and Display machines are located in the Pay and Display car parks. Should infrastructure changes/new technologies become available, this will be reviewed accordingly.
Patient and visitor car parks are regularly patrolled by Car Parking Officers to
provide advice and assistance.
The tariff is reviewed and altered from time to time at the discretion of the

Trusts, in partnership with the Patient Council and guidance from the Department of Health. Parking Tariffs are clearly displayed by ticket machines and available to see on the Trust website (www.mse.nhs.uk).
Short Term Parking: Drop off areas are provided outside the main hospital
entrances and should be used for drop off or pick up only. See appendix 1 for local site parking arrangements.
Disabled Parking: Disabled parking bays are provided free of charge for all

Disabled Blue Badge Holders. They are located in close proximity to the hospital entrances. However, in order to ensure that all roads are not blocked or impeded at any time by vehicles, the Trust does not allow blue badge holders to park on double yellow lines or in hatched boxes at any time.
Travel expenses: The Trusts have a patient travel expenses protocol which

assists those patients in receipt of one of the qualifying benefits or allowances. Travel expenses can be reimbursed on the provision of relevant documentation. This covers bus or train fares, car mileage paid at 15p per mile to and from home address and where applicable a reimbursement of car parking charges. Taxis fares are not refunded, but will be paid at 15p per mile to and from the patients address.
If a patient requires an escort then the correct paperwork stating the patient
needs an escort must be provided. If the patient is a child and coming in by public transport and two parents/guardians are escorting the patient, expenses will only be paid for one escort.
Business visitors will be treated as members of the public and will use the
designated “Patient and Visitor” car parks and pay the appropriate daily tariff.
Official Visitors/Dignitaries: Limited numbers of car parking spaces can be
reserved for official visitors or dignitaries. Requests for reserved parking should be supported by a member of the Executive Team and should be made via the relevant site car parking manager.
Travel Information: Travel information for all our sites can be found on the
internet at www.mse.nhs.uk. This includes information on public transport serving the hospitals. Timetables for public transport services are also at the hospital main entrances.
Free parking for those in greatest need
The current (2020 to 2021) NHS Standard Contract [Service Condition 17.10]

requires that NHS trusts and NHS foundation trusts must comply, where applicable, with NHS car parking guidance. From 1 January 2021, they must ensure that any car parking facilities at the provider's premises for service users, visitors and staff are available free of charge to those groups and at those times identified in, and otherwise in accordance with, that guidance.
This provision will remain in the contract for 2021 to 2022, with the wording updated to reflect that compliance is now an ongoing requirement.
The definitions of these groups are as follows.
Disabled people
A disabled person is a holder of a valid Blue Badge attending hospital as a patient or visitor or is a disabled person employed by the hospital trust.

Disabled patients and visitors receive free parking for the duration of their attendance at, or visit to, the hospital. Disabled employees receive free parking while at the hospital for purposes relating to their employment.
Frequent outpatient attenders

Parking will be provided free to all outpatients who attend hospital for an appointment at least 3 times within a month and for an overall period of at least 3 months. A ‘month' is defined as a period of 30 days.
Parents of sick children staying overnight
The parent of a child in hospital overnight is a parent or guardian of a child or young person, under 18 years of age, who is admitted as an inpatient at hospital overnight.
They receive free parking between the hours of 7.30pm and 8.00am while visiting the child. This would apply to a maximum of 2 vehicles.
Staff working night shifts
Staff working night shifts are members of staff with a shift starting after 7.30pm and ending before 8.00am. They receive free parking for the duration of their shift.
Emergency vehicles and voluntary car service drivers
Emergency vehicles must only park in designated areas which have been
provided near the hospital entrances.
Voluntary car service drivers will be required to drop their passengers off using
the allocated “drop off” areas adjacent to main entrances.
Non-marked emergency vehicles and voluntary car service drivers will be
issued with a parking permit which needs to be clearly displayed in the front window of the vehicle at all times. Parking permits can be obtained by contacting the relevant site parking team.
Delivery and courier drivers
Courier and Delivery Drivers should make deliveries only in designated delivery
areas only.
Delivery vehicles should at all times adhere to site regulations to ensure site
safety and should not cause an obstruction in any area.
Delivery vehicles must be moved as soon as the delivery has been made.
Excessive waiting will result in enforcement notices being applied.
Promoting sustainable forms of transport
Sustainable travel is defined as a mode that improves the physical well-being of

those using it, the environmental wellbeing of all or part of the local area or a combination of the two. Sustainable modes of travel include walking, cycling, buses and other forms of public transport as well as car sharing.
The Trust's Travel Plan sets out an ambition to reduce congestion and pollution
and promote healthier means of travel. It aims to identify and promote sustainable travel initiatives that will enable a reduction in the amount of single car journeys made to our hospitals.
Sustainable travel options for patients and visitors are published on the Trust's
website (www.mse.nhs.uk). Information is provided on all public transport options serving the hospital.
Various schemes and initiatives are available to hospital staff and volunteers to
encourage individuals to consider the way they travel to work. Information on all travel benefits, initiatives and events can be obtained from the Travel section on the staff pages on the Intranet.
Monitoring and audit
The car parking officers will regularly review the condition of car parks and the
car parking manager will regularly review all car parking processes with appropriate stakeholder groups.
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the
effectiveness of the parking policy's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Estates & Facilities Site Managers monthly meeting
Estates & Facilities Site Managers monthly meeting
Progress with the implementation of the sustainable transport initiatives

data.text: The car parking officers will regularly review the condition of car parks and the
car parking manager will regularly review all car parking processes with appropriate stakeholder groups.
Approval and implementation
All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM

Governance Board which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedural guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Estates & Facilities Governance
Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and
meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
References
HTM 07-03 NHS car-parking management: environment and sustainability NHS
car parking guidance 2021 for NHS trusts and NHS foundation trusts
Appendix 1: MSE hospital site parking procedures

table_items.text: Various options are open to staff to pay for parking on site. Staff can either pay monthly as a deduction from salary, via a salary sacrifice arrangement, pay for daily parking (via a scratch card) or pay annually for parking at the cashier's office1.

Two types of staff pass can be produced and programmed for a monthly salary deduction or Top up (pay as you go). - The 24/7 pass is usable in MSCP at all times and visitor car parks at night and weekends after 6pm with exit by 9am following morning - The night and weekend pass available to everyone allowing MSCP and barrier visitor car park use after 6pm with exit by 9am following morning.
BTUH staff pay via salary deduction Our Partners Staff (EPUT, Provide, Boots etc. pay via monthly invoice. Agency / Students pay monthly via the Car Park Kiosk.
Pay & display - Payment machines accept cash only and a change machine is located in the main hospital atrium, by the cashier's office.
Pay machines are sited at hospital entrances – they accept cash, notes and card payments
Pay machines are situated in or close to all Public Car Parks. They are cash, notes or card payments
Patients attending: - chemotherapy - Renal unit - Helen Rollason Centre
Patients attending: - chemotherapy - Radiotherapy dialysis - Extensive rehabilitation - Treatment for deep vein thrombosis

Patients who receive free parking – - Parent of seriously ill child and waiting transfer to another hospitals CCU - A Parent of a child in NICU - Chemotherapy Patient. - Renal Dialysis with Permit. - Primary next of Kin to End of Life patient. - Volunteers. - Dementia Patient's Carer. Concession Parking – - Inpatient longer than 2 weeks. - Patient attending at least twice a week in the following clinic Radiotherapy Dermatology Haematology Cardiothoracic Renal Women and Children's Services - A Parent of a child with learning disabilities and/or Autism. - A Parent with a child in a Paediatric ward after 24 hours.

A PCN will be issued if the Trusts car park policy is not adhered to. The original charge is £80, this is cut to £40 if paid within 14 days. If the amount is not paid within 29 days there are further admin fees that will be

A CPN will only be issued when a clear infringement of the Trust parking regulations has occurred. The penalty fee of the CPN will be reduced by 50% of original value if payment is received by the enforcement company within

occurred. Payment can be made online, by phone or by sending the payment with the payment slip to Gemini.

14 days from the date of issue. Payment of the CPN can only be made by cheque, postal order or on-line to the Enforcement body. Cash will not be accepted. The payment address will be printed on the CPN.
days from the date of issue. Payment of the CPN can only be made by cheque, postal order or on-line to the Enforcement body. Cash will not be accepted. The payment address will be printed on the CPN.
These spaces should be used for drop off or pick up only and will allow for 15 minutes free parking only. Vehicles found parking beyond that time period are susceptible to enforcement.

Unless permitted otherwise visitors/staff who use the drop off bays will be required to stay with their vehicle to avoid enforcement. Staff who require drop off will be added to a list and allocated a maximum of 60 minutes
Patients and Visitors 10 minutes drop of / pick up bays around the hospital. Vehicles found parking beyond that time period are susceptible to enforcement.
